Time Data

ag

Load tidyverse and lubridate

Code 
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)
Code 
# create a bib file for the R packages
# used in this document
# Note! Needs to do a touch ag_date.bib in terminal before first run
# else stops when bibliography: "ag_date.bib" not found in YAML
# first time run
knitr::write_bib(
  c(
    "tidyverse",
    "lubridate"
    ),
  file = "ag_date.bib"
  )

Introduction

  • Date and Times in R are complex
  • In the tidyverse the package lubridate support dates and time.
  • lubridate is not part of core tidyverse so we have to load it with library(lubridate).
  • Since time probably will be of less importance for the data that you will handle we will concentrate on dates

Creating date/times

Tibbles prints them as:

  • Date: <date>

  • Time within a day: <time>

  • date-time: <dttm>

    1. unique instance of time (to nearest second)

    2. sometimes we need even more precision (micro data stock trading).

  • Use the simplest possible type,

    • reduces complexity

  • time is complex because it must handle time zones

How to create a date/time object

  • From a string
  • By combining date-time components
  • From an existing date/time object

Example

Code 
# nine eleven
us_date <- "9-11-2001"
no_date <- "11/9/2001"
typeof(us_date)
[1] "character"
Code 
typeof(no_date)
[1] "character"

To date object; us

Code 
# us date
us_date
[1] "9-11-2001"
Code 
us_d <- mdy(us_date) # note mdy
typeof(us_d)
[1] "double"
Code 
class(us_d)
[1] "Date"

To date object; no

Code 
# no date
no_date
[1] "11/9/2001"
Code 
no_d <- dmy(no_date) #note dmy
typeof(no_d)
[1] "double"
Code 
class(no_d)
[1] "Date"

date-time

Code 
us_date_time <- 09112001202020
no_date_time <- "11/9/2001 20:20:20"
mdy_hms(us_date_time)
[1] "2001-09-11 20:20:20 UTC"
Code 
dmy_hms(no_date_time)
[1] "2001-09-11 20:20:20 UTC"
Code 
as.numeric(mdy_hms(us_date_time))
[1] 1000239620
Code 
as.numeric(dmy_hms(no_date_time))
[1] 1000239620

date-time cont.

Code 
as.numeric(dmy_hms(01011970000001))
[1] 1
  • “UTC” standard not a real time zone,
  • successor to Greenwich Mean Time (GMT),
  • time in different time zones determined from UTC.
  • Never daylight saving time, leap seconds.

Date from combining elements

Code 
set.seed(1234)
my_dates <- tibble(
  y = 1999:2008,
  m = sample(1:12, size = 10, replace = TRUE),
  # make it simple, seed 1234 gives no impossible date
  d = sample(1:31, size = 10, replace = TRUE)
)
my_dates
# A tibble: 10 × 3
       y     m     d
   <int> <int> <int>
 1  1999    12     7
 2  2000    10    22
 3  2001     6    26
 4  2002     5     6
 5  2003    12    15
 6  2004     9    14
 7  2005     5    20
 8  2006     6    14
 9  2007     4    30
10  2008     2    24

Date from combining elements

Code 
my_dates <- my_dates %>% 
  mutate(
    date = make_date(year = y, month = m, day = d),
    # order do not matter
    rev_date = make_date(day = d,  month = m, year = y),
    rev_date2 = format(date, "%d-%m-%y") # now <chr> not date
    )
my_dates
# A tibble: 10 × 6
       y     m     d date       rev_date   rev_date2
   <int> <int> <int> <date>     <date>     <chr>    
 1  1999    12     7 1999-12-07 1999-12-07 07-12-99 
 2  2000    10    22 2000-10-22 2000-10-22 22-10-00 
 3  2001     6    26 2001-06-26 2001-06-26 26-06-01 
 4  2002     5     6 2002-05-06 2002-05-06 06-05-02 
 5  2003    12    15 2003-12-15 2003-12-15 15-12-03 
 6  2004     9    14 2004-09-14 2004-09-14 14-09-04 
 7  2005     5    20 2005-05-20 2005-05-20 20-05-05 
 8  2006     6    14 2006-06-14 2006-06-14 14-06-06 
 9  2007     4    30 2007-04-30 2007-04-30 30-04-07 
10  2008     2    24 2008-02-24 2008-02-24 24-02-08
Code 
#clean up
my_dates <- my_dates %>% 
  select(-rev_date, -rev_date2)

Change type

Code

Code

[1] "2022-08-12 15:10:54 CEST"
Code 
# change type
as_date(now())
[1] "2022-08-12"
Code 
as_datetime(today())
[1] "2022-08-12 UTC"

Different inputs

  • You never know what you have to deal with
  • dmy() and friends are quite smart

Different inputs

  • You never know what you have to deal with
  • dmy() and friends are quite smart
Code 
my_dato <- "11_9_01"
dmy(my_dato)
[1] "2001-09-11"
Code 
my_dato <- "11:9:01"
dmy(my_dato)
[1] "2001-09-11"

What lubridate can’t help us with

Code 
my_dates <- my_dates %>% 
  mutate(
    DMY_rubbish = paste(d, m, str_sub(y,3,4), sep = "")
  )
my_dates
# A tibble: 10 × 5
       y     m     d date       DMY_rubbish
   <int> <int> <int> <date>     <chr>      
 1  1999    12     7 1999-12-07 71299      
 2  2000    10    22 2000-10-22 221000     
 3  2001     6    26 2001-06-26 26601      
 4  2002     5     6 2002-05-06 6502       
 5  2003    12    15 2003-12-15 151203     
 6  2004     9    14 2004-09-14 14904      
 7  2005     5    20 2005-05-20 20505      
 8  2006     6    14 2006-06-14 14606      
 9  2007     4    30 2007-04-30 30407      
10  2008     2    24 2008-02-24 24208

What lubridate can’t help us with

Code 
my_dates %>% select(DMY_rubbish) %>% dmy()
[1] NA
  • The dates in my_dates we could resolve with some reasoning, but values like 11201 are impossible to convert to a date.
  • It could be 1. Dec. 01 (d=1, m=12; y=01) or 11. Feb. 01 (d=11, m=2, y=01).

Rounding dates

  • Nice to have for plotting
  • floor_date() rounds down, ceiling_date() rounds up

    • year: nearest year,

    • month: nearest_month

  • The following does not work
Code 
my_dates[1:5,]
my_dates %>% 
  select(date) %>% 
  floor_date("month")
  • Returns: Error in update.default(x, mdays = 1, hours = 0, minutes = 0, seconds = 0) : need an object with call component

floor_date(), ceiling_date() etc.

  • The following works
Code 
my_dates %>%
  mutate(
    date_dt = as_datetime(date, tz = "UTC"),
    date_dt_fl_y = floor_date(date_dt, "year"),
    date_dt_fl_m = floor_date(date_dt, "month"),
    date_dt_cl_m = ceiling_date(date_dt, "month")
  ) %>% 
  select(date_dt, date_dt_fl_y,
         date_dt_fl_m, date_dt_cl_m) %>% 
  glimpse()
Rows: 10
Columns: 4
$ date_dt      <dttm> 1999-12-07, 2000-10-22, 2001-06-26, 2002-05-06, 2003-12-…
$ date_dt_fl_y <dttm> 1999-01-01, 2000-01-01, 2001-01-01, 2002-01-01, 2003-01-…
$ date_dt_fl_m <dttm> 1999-12-01, 2000-10-01, 2001-06-01, 2002-05-01, 2003-12-…
$ date_dt_cl_m <dttm> 2000-01-01, 2000-11-01, 2001-07-01, 2002-06-01, 2004-01-…

floor_date(), ceiling_date() etc. cont.

  • date_dt_fl_y “rounded” to start of year
  • date_dt_fl_y “rounded” to start of month
  • date_dt_fl_y “rounded” to start of next month

Important option

  • Sunday start of week:
    • week_start = getOption("lubridate.week.start", 7)
  • Monday start of week:
    • week_start = getOption("lubridate.week.start", 1)
Code 
my_dates %>%
  mutate(
    date_dt = as_datetime(date, tz = "UTC"),
    # round to start of week Sunday
    date_dt_fl_w_s = floor_date(date_dt, "week", week_start = getOption("lubridate.week.start", 7)),
    # round to start of week Monday
    date_dt_fl_w_m = floor_date(date_dt, "week", week_start = getOption("lubridate.week.start", 1))
  ) %>%
  select(date_dt, date_dt_fl_w_s, date_dt_fl_w_m) %>%
  head(n = 4)
# A tibble: 4 × 3
  date_dt             date_dt_fl_w_s      date_dt_fl_w_m     
  <dttm>              <dttm>              <dttm>             
1 1999-12-07 00:00:00 1999-12-05 00:00:00 1999-12-06 00:00:00
2 2000-10-22 00:00:00 2000-10-22 00:00:00 2000-10-16 00:00:00
3 2001-06-26 00:00:00 2001-06-24 00:00:00 2001-06-25 00:00:00
4 2002-05-06 00:00:00 2002-05-05 00:00:00 2002-05-06 00:00:00
  • Note! Not necessarily 1 day difference (se line 2)

Setting components

  • We can set individual components of datetime objects (and date) with year(), month() and day().
  • Note! We need datetime objects, date objects must be converted to datetime.
Code 
# Does not work
my_dates %>% 
  select(date) %>%
  update(year = year(my_dates$date) + 10, month = 11)

Setting components

Code 
# This does work
my_dates <- my_dates %>% 
  mutate(
    date_dt = as_datetime(date, tz = "Europe/Oslo"),
    date_dt_new = update(date_dt, year = 2015)
  )

my_dates %>% 
  select(date, date_dt, date_dt_new) %>% 
  head(n = 3)
# A tibble: 3 × 3
  date       date_dt             date_dt_new        
  <date>     <dttm>              <dttm>             
1 1999-12-07 1999-12-07 00:00:00 2015-12-07 00:00:00
2 2000-10-22 2000-10-22 00:00:00 2015-10-22 00:00:00
3 2001-06-26 2001-06-26 00:00:00 2015-06-26 00:00:00
  • Why 01:00:00 and 02:00:00 in third column?
    • Day light saving time

  • More examples of Day light saving time
Code

  select(date, date_dt)
# A tibble: 10 × 2
   date       date_dt            
   <date>     <dttm>

 2 2000-10-22 2000-10-22 00:00:00
 3 2001-06-26 2001-06-26 00:00:00
 4 2002-05-06 2002-05-06 00:00:00

10 2008-02-24 2008-02-24 00:00:00

Time spans

  • Duration, number of seconds
  • Periods, weeks, months etc.
  • Intervals, starting and endpoints
  • Subtract two dates and you get a difftime object
  • For details about time zones see 16.5 in r4ds.

An example: my_life

  • Playing with time and writing a function
Code 
my_life <- function(birthday = "25121964", unit = "weeks") {
# find the difference between today and birthday measured in unit
life = as.numeric(difftime(today(), dmy(birthday), units = unit))
# one case for each unit
case_when(
 unit == "weeks" ~ paste("You are about", life, "weeks old."),
 unit == "days" ~ paste("You are about", life , "days old."),
 unit == "hours" ~ paste("You are about", life, "hours old."),
 unit == "mins" ~ paste("You are about", life, "minutes old."),
 unit == "secs" ~ paste("You are about", life, "seconds old.")
  )
}
my_life() # with default values
[1] "You are about 3007 weeks old."

An example: my_life

  • some are just too young to play with R
Code 
my_life <- function(birthday = "25121964", unit = "weeks") {
# too young to play with R, week as unit
if (as.numeric(difftime(today(), dmy(birthday), units = "weeks"))/52.25 < 5) {
return("You are far too young to play with R!")
}
# find the difference between today and birthday measured in unit
life = as.numeric(difftime(today(), dmy(birthday), units = unit))
# one case for each unit
case_when(
 unit == "weeks" ~ paste("You are about", life, "weeks old."),
 unit == "days" ~ paste("You are about", life , "days old."),
 unit == "hours" ~ paste("You are about", life, "hours old."),
 unit == "mins" ~ paste("You are about", life, "minutes old."),
 unit == "secs" ~ paste("You are about", life, "seconds old.")
  )
}
Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "weeks")
[1] "You are about 3007 weeks old."

An example: my_life

  • Perhaps we should round off our answer.
Code 
my_life <- function(birthday = "01012020", unit = "weeks") {
  # find the difference between today and birthday with week as unit
  life_w <- as.numeric(difftime(today(), dmy(birthday), units = "weeks"))
  # too young to play with R, week as unit
  if (life_w / 52.25 < 5) {
    return("You are far too young to play with R!")
  } else {
    # find the difference between today and birthday measured in unit
    life = round(as.numeric(difftime(today(), dmy(birthday), units = unit)), 0)
    # one case for each unit
    case_when(
      unit == "weeks" ~ paste("You are about", life, "weeks old."),
      unit == "days" ~ paste("You are about", life, "days old."),
      unit == "hours" ~ paste("You are about", life, "hours old."),
      unit == "mins" ~ paste("You are about", life, "minutes old."),
      unit == "secs" ~ paste("You are about", life, "seconds old.")
    )
  }
}
my_life(01032016)
[1] "You are about 336 weeks old."

Testing my_life()

Code 
my_life("01032005", unit = "weeks")
[1] "You are about 910 weeks old."
Code 
my_life("01032005", unit = "days")
[1] "You are about 6373 days old."
Code 
my_life("01032005", unit = "mins")
[1] "You are about 9177120 minutes old."
Code 
my_life("01032005", unit = "secs")
[1] "You are about 550627200 seconds old."

An example my_life

  • What about years and months
  • difftime() does not do months and years
  • We can get an approximation

Full function

Code 
my_life <- function(birthday = today(), unit = "years") {
  stopifnot(unit %in% c("years", "months", "weeks", "days", "hours", "mins", "secs"))
  life_w = difftime(today(), dmy(birthday), units = "weeks")
if (as.numeric(life_w)/52.25 < 5) {
return("You are far too young to learn R!")
} else if (unit %in% c("years", "months")) {
  case_when(
 unit == "years" ~ paste("You are about", round(as.numeric(life_w)/52.25, 2), "years old."),
 unit == "months" ~ paste("You are about", round(as.numeric(life_w)/(52.25/12), 2), "months old.")
)
} else {
life = round(as.numeric(difftime(today(), dmy(birthday), units = unit)), 0)
case_when(
 unit == "weeks" ~ paste("You are about", life, "weeks old."),
 unit == "days" ~ paste("You are about", life , "days old."),
 unit == "hours" ~ paste("You are about", life, "hours old."),
 unit == "mins" ~ paste(
   "You are about", 
   formatC(life, format = "f", big.mark = ".",
           digits = 0, decimal.mark = ","),
   "minutes old."),
 unit == "secs" ~ paste(
   "You are about",
   formatC(life, format = "f", big.mark = ".",
           digits = 0, decimal.mark = ","),
   "seconds old.")
  )
}
}

Final testing

Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "years")
[1] "You are about 57.55 years old."
Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "months")
[1] "You are about 690.6 months old."
Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "weeks")
[1] "You are about 3007 weeks old."
Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "days")
[1] "You are about 21049 days old."
Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "hours")
[1] "You are about 505176 hours old."
Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "mins")
[1] "You are about 30.310.560 minutes old."
Code 
my_life("25-12-1964", unit = "secs")
[1] "You are about 1.818.633.600 seconds old."
